Whether you're just starting out or have been working with React for years, we‚Äôve all hit those moments where something just didn‚Äôt click right away. üß† useEffect ‚Äì kept getting stuck in dependency hell. üîÑ Lifting state up ‚Äì It made sense eventually, but at first, it was a mess. üîÅ Re-renders and performance issues ‚Äì Especially with large components. entry.title: 230/365 | ¬•10M Job Challenge - Interview Preparation
entry.summary: I recently updated and streamlined my resume based on my recent work experience. The longer your career history, the harder it actually becomes to write a strong resume or perform well in interviews. It‚Äôs easy for there to be gaps between what you‚Äôve done and what‚Äôs expected. But at the very least, I want to clearly communicate my experience ‚Äî essentially, to market myself. So I put together a few key points for interviews: A concise and impactful resume Be able to hold a conversation ‚Äî do some research on the company and prepare a few topics to help ease interview tension Understand both your strengths and weaknesses (highlight strengths without sounding arrogant, and explain what actions you've taken to improve your weaknesses) Make sure your traits align with the role you're applying for No matter what you're trying to learn, it always takes time. But before anything else, it's important to know how to express yourself well, and anticipate what questions might come up based on your experience. I always stick to the STAR method: Situation Task Action Result I tend to get nervous and have trouble showing my full potential, so I keep reminding myself that interviews go both ways ‚Äî companies are also looking for the right person to do the job. At worst, I treat each one as practice. Confidence takes practice; it's not just about telling yourself to ‚Äúbe confident.‚Äù With a busy schedule, it often feels like my goals are far away, but I believe I‚Äôm gradually getting closer. Never give up!

entry.title: I built a headless React chatbot widget for full UI control

üß± I built a headless React chatbot widget so devs can fully control the UI üëâ @candoa/chatbot is a headless React chatbot widget built for devs who love: full UI freedom, TailwindCSS, React Hooks, and minimal dependencies. ‚ö° Key Features Conversation persistence (localStorage) Greeting messages Typing indicators Error handling Demo GIF: https://candoa-public.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/chatbot-ezgif.com-loop-count.gif üõ†Ô∏è Install npm install @candoa/chatbot yarn add @candoa/chatbot üì¶ Example import { useChatbot } from '@candoa/chatbot' const { state, actions } = useChatbot('your-project-id') return (
{state.messages.map((m) => (
{m.text}
))}
) I‚Äôm a solo dev working on this. Would love your feedback or ideas! https://github.com/aamancio/candoa-chatbot

entry.title: üß† Backing Fields in C#: What They Are and Why You Should Care
Efficient Route Planning for Robotic Vacuums: Algorithms, Challenges, and Real-World Use
entry.summary: Robotic vacuums have revolutionized the way we think about home and commercial cleaning. These smart devices traverse rooms autonomously, mapping environments and avoiding obstacles to ensure thorough and efficient cleaning. But behind the scenes, a complex web of algorithms enables these robots to plan and execute efficient cleaning routes. In this blog post, we will delve into the core programming concepts that power robotic vacuum navigation. We'll explore various pathfinding algorithms, present Python code examples, and discuss the real-world implications for cleaning services. Efficient route planning is crucial for robotic vacuums to: Maximize battery life Minimize cleaning time Ensure full area coverage Reduce mechanical wear Poor path planning can lead to missed spots, redundant co‚Ä¶

entry.title: Data Warehousing and Data Mining
entry.summary:
15-Marks Questions (Frequency >= 3)
Frequency: 6 Question: a) Introduce the concept of data mining and cite two application areas. b) What are the different steps of a data mining task? c) Suppose that the data mining task is to cluster the following eight points (with (x, y) representing location) into 3 clusters. ... Use k-means algorithm to determine the three clusters. WBUT Years: [2010, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2016, 2018] Source Page: 9 (Long Answer Type Questions, Q3) Frequency: 6 Question: a) What is clustering? Why is it required for data warehousing and data mining? What are the differences between partitioning clustering and Hierarchical clustering? OR, What is clustering? What are the features of good cluster? What do you mean by hierarchical clustering technique? WBUT Y‚Ä¶

entry.title: Millau - ingress-proxy with self-configuration for Docker Swarm
entry.summary: Ashamed to admit, I still use Swarm in 2025. It's easy to explain, quick to set up, and simple to use. It's a starting point in the world of containers when full-blown Kubernetes is overkill. But Docker's evolution hasn't been the most straightforward. Over time, it began to lack a minimal dynamic proxy for Swarm - one that you run once, which configures traffic routing to microservices automatically - and forget about it. That's how Millau was born - an ingress-proxy and load balancer based on labels. It currently powers its own website and a few other projects. If you've ever deployed services in Docker Swarm, you've encountered the question of routing external traffic: how to organize access from the outside to the desired services inside the stack. Sure, you can use Nginx, HAProxy, or ‚Ä¶

entry.title: From Vision to Code: How I‚Äôm Building Orbeato to Modernize Education with AI
entry.summary:
Hi Devs! üëã Keshav Kushwaha, a developer, dreamer, and the founder of Enthrox, a tech company on a mission to transform how schools use technology. I‚Äôm currently building Orbeato, a student-focused AI chatbot that helps with learning, questions, and clear, accurate answers.
In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through: Why I started Enthrox What Orbeato does How we‚Äôre using AI to help students The challenges and vision ahead üöÄ The Origin of Enthrox I‚Äôve always believed that schools shouldn‚Äôt be left behind as the world becomes more intelligent. While tech has changed how we shop, work, and socialize, most schools are still stuck in outdated systems. Enthrox was born from that frustration ‚Äî and from a belief that we can build something better. Our mission is simple: bring modern AI and digital too‚Ä¶

entry.title: Naming Things in Code: Why It‚Äôs Hard and How to Do It Better
entry.summary: Hi there! I'm Maneshwar. Right now, I‚Äôm building LiveAPI, a first-of-its-kind tool for helping you automatically index API endpoints across all your repositories. LiveAPI helps you discover, understand, and use APIs in large tech infrastructures with ease. Naming variables and functions is deceptively tricky for every developer. We‚Äôve all experienced it: staring at code, unable to remember if we called that counter count, num, or c. Modern IDEs with autocomplete make it easy to lean on the editor to finish names for us, but this is a crutch. Choosing good names is one of the hardest problems in programming. Naming feels hard because it requires precision in thought and empathy with future readers. A name must capture the intent of the code and remain accurate even as code evolves. Yo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Now you can build API like LEGO
entry.summary: Hey again devs! Quick update on CFFBRW (my visual API builder I posted about earlier). So I got some feedback that the workflow builder felt... well, kinda basic while being overwhelming (I am confused!). One dev literally said "this looks like my nephew's Scratch project" üòÖ Fair point. The drag-and-drop Sortable was functional but not exactly inspiring confidence for production use. Two big updates that I have implemented over the week: 1. Rebuilt the whole visual editor with Google Blockly Now workflows snap together like LEGO blocks. You can see the data flow, nest components properly, and it actually feels solid. Plus, Blockly is battle-tested by millions of students worldwide - if it can survive middle schoolers, it can handle my API workflows. 2. Added a Python runtime component (!)‚Ä¶

entry.title: CATL Introduces Choco-SEB Battery Swapping Technology
entry.summary: There is no doubt that electric vehicles have become a major segment of the automotive industry, with many players introducing new technologies to strengthen their presence in the market. One of them is the Chinese battery manufacturer CATL, which has launched a new battery swapping technology known as Choco-SEB (Swapping Electric Block).
